name: Carnations
climate: Carnations thrive in temperate climates where the seasons are mild and not extreme.
They prefer climates with cool winters and warm summers, avoiding extreme heat.
Carnations are well-suited for Mediterranean climates with dry summers and wet winters.
They do best in climates that offer moderate temperatures and avoid harsh frosts.
sunlight: Carnations require full sunlight to perform their best, ideally 6-8 hours a day.
They should be planted in locations where they can receive direct sunlight most of the day.
Partial shade is tolerable but can result in fewer blooms and slower growth.
Avoid planting in areas that are too heavily shaded, as this will hinder flowering.
watering: Carnations benefit from regular watering to keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy.
Ensure good drainage to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot.
During dry periods, increase watering frequency to prevent plant stress.
Allowing the top layer of soil to dry between waterings helps avoid overhydration.
soil: Well-drained, sandy loam soil is ideal for growing healthy carnations.
A soil pH of 6.0 to 7.0 is preferred to accommodate nutrient absorption.
Improve soil with organic matter to enhance drainage and fertility.
Heavy clay soils should be amended to improve aeration and prevent water stagnation.
toxic: Carnations are mildly toxic to pets such as cats and dogs if ingested.
extra_care_tip: Deadhead flowers regularly after blooming to encourage further flowering.
